Javascript testing with Rails and QUnit

December 22nd, 2013

Testing a Rails backend is considerably easier than that of its ugly frontend javascript brother. When looking for a solution to frontend testing solution, I usually look for the following:

  • Easily runnable
  • Simple configuration
  • CI friendly (TravisCI would be nice)
  • Rails asset loading

And some bonuses:

  • Multiple browser testing support
  • Code coverage reports

Finding all these that played nicely was extremely difficult. Initially, I settled on using the rails-qunit gem. This does quite a nice job for a little while. There is a nice generator included making for an easy setup. Simply fire up the rails server and hit /qunit and you're tests will run.

However, I desperately wanted these tests to be part of my Travis build. Especially with the rise of single page applications (SPA), the javascript quickly became the most important of my app to test. Now let me introduce you to a wonderful gem called teaspoon. Teaspoon comes with support with Jasmine, Mocha and QUnit. It's an amazing little testing library.

def foo
  puts 'foo'
end
